notes.div: Recommended for all students wanting a nonmathematical look at basic discoveries of physics.

description.div: Qualitative approach to physics for the non-science major that emphasizes concepts and how they are used to understand the everyday physical world. Newton's description of motion and forces, the atomic view of matter, kinds and transformations of energy, the nature of electricity and magnetism, sound and light waves, and subatomic particles. Some topics selected according to student interest.

notes.div: Credit toward the degree may be earned in only one of: PHYS 141, 141H, and 151. Lab fee required.

description.div: Mechanics, heat, waves and sound.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors program or by invitation; MATH 102 or equivalent.

notes.div: Credit toward the degree may be earned in only one of: PHYS 141, 141H, and 151. Lab fee required.

description.div: For course description, see PHYS 141.
Continuation of PHYS 141. Electricity, magnetism, optics, relativity, atomic and nuclear physics.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors program or by invitation; PHYS 141 or 141H.

description.div: For course description, see PHYS 142.

prerequisite.div: MATH 102 or equivalent high school preparation.

notes.div: Credit toward the degree may be earned in only one of: PHYS 141, 141H, and 151.

description.div: Short course, without laboratory, for those who need one semester of elementary general physics. Emphasis on understanding our physical environment through application of principles of mechanics, heat, sound, electricity, and light.
Laboratory experiments in mechanics, heat, and wave motion.
Topic varies.

course.title: Honors: Modern Topics in Physics and Astronomy

description.div: Seminar/workshop that introduces students to topics in modern physics research in basic and applied areas. Students given an understanding of how their studies relate to current progress in physics and astronomy and to prepare for careers in physics-related disciplines.

prerequisite.div: One year high school physics or PHYS 141 or 141H or 151 or permission; MATH 106 or parallel.

description.div: Calculus-based course intended for students in engineering and the physical sciences. Mechanics, fluids, wave motion, and heat.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation; MATH 106 or 106H or equivalent or parallel.

description.div: For course description, see PHYS 211.

prerequisite.div: One year high school physics or PHYS 211 or 211H or permission; MATH 107 or parallel.

description.div: Continuation of PHYS 211. Electricity, magnetism, and optics.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation; PHYS 211 or 211H; MATH 107 or equivalent or parallel.

description.div: For course description, see PHYS 212.
Continuation of PHYS 212. Relativity, quantum mechanics, atoms, and nuclei.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors program or by invitation; PHYS 212 or 212H; MATH 208 or 208H, or parallel.

description.div: Continuation of PHYS 212H. Relativity, quantum mechanics, atoms, and nuclei.
Experiments in mechanics, heat and wave motion.
Laboratory experiments in electromagnetism and optics.
Experiments in atomic and nuclear physics.

course.title: Elections, Political Parties, and Special Interests

description.div: Roles of political parties and interest groups in government and politics, focusing on their efforts of elections and lobbying.
Diode, transistor, and operational amplifier circuits and analog applications; gates, flip-flops, and elementary digital electronics.

course.title: Liberal Arts Physics: Matter and Motion

notes.div: PHYS 260 and 261 are independent and may be taken in any order.

description.div: Basic concepts of physics in a historical context and in relationship to the intellectual development of humankind. Mechanics, heat gravitation, and structure of the universe.

course.title: Liberal Arts Physics: Atoms and Fields

notes.div: PHYS 260 and 261 are independent and may be taken in any order.

description.div: Basic concepts of physics in a historical context and in relationship to the intellectual development of humankind. Atomic structure of matter, states of matter, waves, and light. Practical consequences of the properties of matter and physical phenomena.

notes.div: Intended for students planning to be elementary or middle-level teachers

description.div: Selected physical science concepts using inquiry methods.

prerequisite.div: PHYS 212 or parallel; MATH 221 or parallel; or permission.

description.div: Review of vector operations and of the kinematics and dynamics of a particle. Dynamics of a system of particles, motion of rigid bodies, central force problems, collisions, Lagrangian techniques, oscillations, and coupled oscillators.

course.title: Physics of Lasers and Modern Optics

prerequisite.div: PHYS 142 or 212; and a lab course in science or engineering.

description.div: Physical principles and techniques of lasers and modern optics. Emphasis on practical experience with state-of-the-art techniques and applications.

prerequisite.div: PHYS 142 or 212 with a grade of C+ or better.

description.div: Some of the concepts and ideas underlying modern areas of physics through readings from non-technical works by noted physicists and science writers. Includes quantum mechanics, relativity, cosmology, chaos, and examples of modern technology.
Research participation.

prerequisite.div: Open to candidates for degrees with distinction, with high distinction, and with highest distinction in the College of Arts and Sciences.

description.div: Re-formulation of physics problems for solution on a computer, control of errors in numerical work, and programming.

course.title: Introduction to Physics and Chemistry of Solids

prerequisite.div: PHYS 213 or CHEM 481/881, MATH 220/820 or 221/821, or permission.

description.div: Introduction to structural, thermal, electrical, and magnetic properties of solids, based on concepts of atomic structure, chemical bonding in molecules, and electron states in solids. Principles underlying molecular design of materials and solid-state devices.
Thermal phenomena from the point of view of thermodynamics, kinetic theory, and statistical mechanics.
Methods and techniques of modern experimental physics.
Continuation of PHYS 441/841.
Continuation of PHYS 442/842.
Theory of electric and magnetic fields and their interaction with charges and currents, Maxwell's equations, electric and magnetic properties of matter.

Production of electromagnetic waves, wave guides and cavities, properties of waves, plane waves, reflection and refraction, interference and coherence phenomena, polarization. Optical properties of matter.
Basic concepts and formalism of quantum mechanics with applications to simple systems.
Basic concepts and experimental foundation for an understanding of the physics of atoms, nuclei, and elementary particles.

course.title: Introduction to Lasers and Laser Applications

description.div: Physics of electronic transition production stimulated emission of radiation. Threshold conditions for laser oscillation. Types of lasers and their applications in engineering.

notes.div: Offered as need arises to treat special topics not covered in other 400/800-level physics courses.

description.div: Topics vary.
